title: Identify the mobile number of a twitter user

profile.name: X (Formerly Twitter)
profile.about: X helps you create and share ideas and information instantly, without barriers.

vulnerability_information:
**Summary:** 
By exploiting this security vulnerability we can detect the mobile number of a twitter user.


**Description:**
This security vulnerability is of type "Information disclosure" it allows to exploit Flawed behavior of the twitter system to obtain distinct responses when different error states occur.
This security vulnerability allows to identify the mobile number of a twitter user from its USER_NAME.

## Steps To Reproduce:

We explain how to get the mobile number which is (██████████) from the following twitter user "███"==> USER_NAME = ████

1.access the following url: "████" and enter user name "██████" and click search. (see screenshot "1.PNG")
2. At this step twitter  displays the last 2 digits of mobile number through this message "text a code to the phone number ending in 15", the last two digits are 15, click on next.(see screenshot "2.PNG")
3. repeat step number 2 several times, i.e. repeat asking to receive the code several times until you get the following message: "You've exceeded the number of attempts. Please try again later."(see screenshot "3.PNG")
4.Now twitter  block sends it sms code to the number associated with the victim's twitter  account which ends with two digits 15

====> twitter  block sends it again sms for the correct victim mobile number, ie "████████" but it does not block it sends sms to any other different mobile number at ███ (the probability that twitter block sends an sms to mobile number different to █████████ which ends in 15 and has the following format &&&&&&15 at the time of launching the attack is 0.000001% ) so we can use the "Forgot Password" feature and ask to receive an sms on all the following format numbers &&&&&&15 and the attempt which returns the following message: "You've exceeded the number of attempts. Please try again later."is an attempt associated with the victim mobile number.

==> an attempt to receive an SMS code at the mobile number of the following format: &&&&&&15 may return 3 different messages:
1st message : Number not associated with a twitter  account
2nd message : "You'll recive a code to verify here so you can reset your accont password." ==> this is not the victim mobile number .(see screenshot "7.PNG" and "8.PNG" )
3rd message: "You've exceeded the number of attempts. Please try again later". ==> this is the victim mobile number (see screenshot "4.PNG" and "5.PNG" and "6.PNG"  )


5. to identify the mobile number we will access this url "████████" and try to request sms code on all the mobile numbers that end by 15 which follows this format &&&&&&15 that is to say make a brute force on all the number which ends in 15, therefore the request which tries to recive sms code associating with the correct victim number account will display the following message: "You've exceeded the number of attempts. Please try again later" on the other side any other request that is not associated with victim's correct mobile number will display the following message: "You'll recive a code to verify here so you can reset your accont password." or a number not associated with a twitter account.


===>we can deduce the number of victim's digit according to the user's country or we can easily deduce it, the victim's country is "██████" so the format of its number is as follows: &&&&&&15, To accelerate the brute force and decipher the correct digits more quickly associated with this number &&&&&&15 we will use the following information:
the mobile number for the ████ region begins with the following operator phone code: (26-27) (56-57)
, so we are now going to brute force on this number range:
26&&&&15 ... 27 &&&&15
56&&&&15 ... 57&&&&15

we have 10 ^ 4 = 10000 mobile number to test each time to identify the correct victim mobile number, we eliminate the numbers that are not associated with a twitter account then determine which number blocked by twitter from receiving sms that returns the message next: "You've exceeded the number of attempts. Please try again later" , this is the victim mobile number.

## Impact: [add why this issue matters]
This issue has a critical impact on user privacy

## Impact

Attacker has a critical impact on the confidentiality  of the twitter user

activities.message:
Thank you for your report.

We have tested the behavior depicted in your submission, and we could not reproduce the intended impact. In our tests, using our account username, we made requests to `begin_password_reset` until we encountered the "You've exceeded the number of attempts. Please try again later" page, and did not receive SMS codes any longer. We then used a **different account’s** phone number on the `begin_password_reset` page, and encountered the "You've exceeded the number of attempts. Please try again later" page. This would indicate that you could not enumerate phone numbers using this method, as both the “correct” phone number or any valid phone number would return this error. 

Is there anything we’re missing here? 

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security.

Hello,

Your investigation is incorrect because you used only one ip address.
please redo an invsigation with the following scenario:
1.access to the "begin_password_reset" page and enter username "███"
2.repeat step number 1 several times, i.e. repeat asking to receive the code several times until you get the following message: "You've exceeded the number of attempts. Please try again later."

3.Change your ip address
4. Access the "begin_password_reset" page and enter the correct mobile number of victim ██████████, the following message is displayed "" You've exceeded the number of attempts. Please try again later "."
5. Access the "begin_password_reset" page and enter an incorrect mobile number has the following format &&&&&&15, the following message is displayed "You'll recive a code to verify here so you can reset your accont password."

Attached a video which explains the above steps.

Regards

Thank you for your report @aymen_mansour,

>5. Access the "begin_password_reset" page and enter an incorrect mobile number has the following format &&&&&&15, the following message is displayed "You'll recive a code to verify here so you can reset your accont password."

We are unable to reproduce this behavior using our account. In our test, we receive the "We couldn't find your account with that information " error, when we enter a  incorrect mobile number on `███████` page.  

In addition, we are having a bit of trouble understanding how this step relates to your brute force attack. Can you provide us modified steps to reproduce that clearly explain how you would perform this Bruteforce attack against an arbitrary account? 

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security.

Hello,

First of all I confirm that this method can cause a data leak.

how does this brute force atack work?

1. we have blocked user "███" from receiving sms using a 1st ip address. in this step we have two pieces of information:
- the mobile number of "████████" ends with two digits which are 15 and has 8 digits (because his country is ███ (a mobile number from ████████ contains 8 digits)
- very sensitive information: the following message is displayed "" You've exceeded the number of attempts. Please try again later. "" If we go to the "begin_password_reset" and try to enter the correct victim number "█████████" using a 2nd ip address.

2. we know that the mobile number has 8 digits and ends with 15 (&&&&&&15), let's see what happens if we do a brute force made up of 4 attempts on "" begin_password_reset ":

- a 1st attempt at a mobile number which ends in 15 and composed of 8 digits for example "███████" the following message is displayed "You'll recive a code to verify here so you can reset your accont password." ==> this is not the correct victim mobile number because there is no SMS block.

- a 2nd attempt at a mobile number which ends with 15 and composed of 8 digits for example "██████" the following message is displayed "You'll recive a code to verify here so you can reset your accont password." ==> this is not the correct victim mobile number because there is no SMS block.

-a 3rd attempt at a mobile number which ends with 15 and composed of 8 digits for example "███████" the following message is displayed "We couldn't find your account with that information" ==> this is not the correct mobile victim number because it is not associated with a Twitter account.

-a 4th attempt of mobile number which ends with 15 for example "████" the following message is displayed "" "You've exceeded the number of attempts. Please try again later." "" ==> this is the correct victim mobile number because there is a SMS block.

Please see the video and try to follow their steps it explains the point of change of ip address, we can check if the mobile number is blocked from receiving sms or not, the 1st mobile number is blocked, the 2nd mobile number n 'is not blocked.

Regards

Hello,

I am familiar with the password reset process. do not hesitate to ask me questions for any clarification concerning the attack scenario.

The idea is to block a user from resetting his password through his username then brute force in a list of mobile number (which contains the last two digits of victim and a determined number of digits) and to identify the mobile number blocked, it is the victim's mobile number

Regards

Thank you for your response @aymen_mansour,

We can reproduce the behavior you described, but we would like to ask you another question before we move forward with your report. In this attack, you are using an account specific rate limit to verify the phone number associated with a user's account. While this behavior is not be ideal, removing this account specific rate limit would allow attackers to send an excessive number of "Password" reset requests to the victim's mobile device.

Do you have any suggested fixes or mitigations that you feel we might implement to address this behavior without allowing attacker's to spam user's with  "Password" reset requests?

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security.

Hello,

The behavior can be solved without allowing attackers to spam users with "password" reset requests.

Whatever the request sent by a user to reset his password the following message should display "we have sent you a verification code if you have not exceeded your password reset limit".

This message will replace the previous sensitive message "You've exceeded the number of attempts. Please try again later."

And also replaces this message "You'll recive a code to verify here so you can reset your accont password." "

ie we will send the following message "we have sent you a verification code if you have not exceeded your password reset limit" "whatever the request sent by a user.

In the background the system must send a verification code to the mobile number if the user has not exceeded a rate limit, for example 10 sms code.

In this way we kept the rate limit specific to the account and we protected the system against an information disclosure attack and the attacker cannot know if the mobile number is blocked or not from receiving sms codes.

Regards

Hello,

The security vulnerability reported in this report can cause a massive data leak. it is clear that the impact is critical on the confidentiality of user data.

Regards

Thank you for your response @aymen_mansour,

We are investigating the behavior you described and will get back to you when we have more information.

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security

Thank you for your report. We believe it may be a valid security issue and will investigate it further. It could take some time to find and update the root cause for an issue, so we thank you for your patience.

Thank you for helping keep Twitter secure!

Thanks again. As mentioned we’ll keep you updated as we investigate further. As a reminder, please remember to keep the details of this report private until we have fully investigated and addressed the issue.

Hello,

Please provide an update for the resolution of this security issue.

Regards

Hello,

Can give you the state of progress of this case ?

Regards

Thank you for your patience.
We consider this issue to be fixed now. Can you please confirm?

Thank you for helping keep Twitter secure!

Hello,

I confirm that this vulnerability has been fixed and an attacker cannot obtain the mobile number associated with the user.

Regard

Hello Twitter team,

Can you disclosure it please?

Regards
